channel.title: Music Game help
channel.description:
Since I have plenty of time to spend in my Java class, I've decided I want to create an applet that plays notes on a piano. Right now I'm working on getting all of the notes (about 5 Octives) and getting them all in flats, naturals, and sharps. I've barely started with the code. The program will play a note when you hit a key on the keyboard. It will play the note as a sharp,flat, or natural if you have another key down (shift + f will play the note which corresponds to the f key on the keyboard as a sharp). So the program will read key inputs and play sounds.
1. Is this a viable program? 2. Are there any better ways I could go about making this program? (Easier or more organised code I could use) 3. What is the command for: if the F key is down 4. If I keep down a key will it play the sound file over and over again?
Yes, I do play an instrument. I will update this when I have more questions. Oh yea, my style might suck a little.
Stuff I'll add when I'm done with the basics: 1.On screen keyboard which shows which keys you have down. 2.Recorder to record what you've played and play it back. 3.Volume control 4.Editable key bindings. 5.Song tutorials.

item.title: Music Game help
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Not sure if this would be to any help, but here is a SoundHandler class that I made a while ago:

[code]/** SoundHandler.java */

import javax.sound.sampled.AudioFormat;
import javax.sound.sampled.AudioSystem;
import javax.sound.sampled.LineUnavailableException;
import javax.sound.sampled.SourceDataLine;

public abstract class SoundHandler {
private static final float SAMPLE_RATE = 8000f;

 private SoundHandler() {
      
 }
 
 
 
 public static void play(int hertz, int millis) {
      try {
           byte[] byteBuffer = new byte[1];
           
           AudioFormat audioFormat = new AudioFormat(SAMPLE_RATE, 8, 1, true, false);
           
           SourceDataLine sourceDataLine = AudioSystem.getSourceDataLine(audioFormat);
           sourceDataLine.open(audioFormat);
           sourceDataLine.start();
           
           for(int i = 0; i < millis * 8; i++) {
                double angle = i / (SAMPLE_RATE / hertz) * 2.0 * Math.PI;
                
                byteBuffer[0] = (byte)(Math.sin(angle) * 110.0);
                
                sourceDataLine.write(byteBuffer, 0, 1);
           }
           
           sourceDataLine.drain();
           sourceDataLine.stop();
           sourceDataLine.close();
      }
      catch(LineUnavailableException e) {
           
      }
 }

}[/code]
